title: Citi insists its new Málaga office isn't a gimmick
text:
One scoop to start: UK chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng is seeking to scrap Britain's cap on bankers' bonuses, introduced after the 2008 financial crash, in a controversial move to boost the City of London's global competitiveness.

In today's newsletter:

  • Junior bankers head to Málaga

  • Growth investors confront the tech rout

  • Microsoft-Activision's regulatory woes

The City or La Ciudad? A junior banker's dilemma

An unseasonable chill has descended upon Wall Street recently, even as the rest of Manhattan basks in the late September sun.

Not that the 27 Citigroup analysts who just touched down in Málaga have noticed.

The US investment bank is celebrating the opening of its new hub for junior investment bankers in the sunny Spanish city, a move it insists is not a gimmick as lenders battle for young talent amid criticism of burnout issues and waning financial resources.

Meanwhile, their New York-based peers, who accepted six-figure salaries, Pelotons and other perks in exchange for gruelling 95-hour workweeks, find themselves in a more precarious position.

Goldman Sachs is readying a round of job cuts in the coming weeks and things aren't looking much better at JPMorgan Chase, as a dealmaking and IPO slowdown threatens to drag third-quarter investment banking revenues to half as much as the previous year's.

For Citi's newest recruits, there's a trade-off to working in Málaga, which promises eight-hour days and work-free weekends: staff there will be paid about half the starting salaries allotted to first-year analysts in London and New York.

Citi insists it's a deal that suits both its employees and the bank. “We suffer from a lot of churn like the rest of the industry, we lose talent to private equity and tech, so we are eager to understand if we can stop that by offering a better work-life balance,” said Manolo Falcó, the lender's global co-head of investment banking.

The 3,000 applicants who applied to the two-year programme seem to agree. But rivals have dismissed the idea as a stunt that could ultimately harm those who choose to launch their careers in the more laid-back setting. 

If HBO's City drama Industry is to hold any truths, the initial long hours are all too common for early career bankers. What will Málaga alumni's future bosses make of their requests for better work-life balance?

Wall Street claims to have made strides since the infamous “working conditions survey” compiled by burnt-out junior Goldmanites, which led banks to raise salaries as a means to survive the onslaught of deals over the past two years.

Citi, which has struggled in the past to match its rivals in terms of pay, thinks it has found a way to solve the problem of recruiting and retaining young talent without simply throwing money at it.

DD is keen to see how they fare when their two years are up. “If you want to go all the way, you have to move from Málaga eventually,” said Falcó.

Plight of the tech bulls

In the height of the retail trading and meme stock frenzy, Cathie Wood rode to fame on her bullish tech bets — so much so that it inspired T-shirts crowning her “The Queen of the bull market”.

Wood is one in a group of prominent growth investors to be knocked off their thrones by the recent tech sell-off, the FT's Harriet Agnew reports, calling into question the future of an industry powered by high-stakes bets on a technological revolution that hasn't quite lived up to expectations.

The star stockpicker's flagship exchange-traded fund Ark Innovation has dropped about 55 per cent this year to date, while her firm Ark Investment Management has lost almost half of its assets under management since December.

DD readers will be familiar with the travails of SoftBank's Masayoshi Son. The Japanese tech bull declared himself “ashamed” following steep losses by his flagship Vision Funds in the first half of the year and sold off a majority of his most successful investment in Alibaba in a frantic effort to assuage investors.

Tiger Global founder Chase Coleman, a protégé of the late Julian Robertson, has been similarly humbled. Both Coleman and Son are now in “defensive mode”, slashing their equities exposures and biding their time atop swelling cash piles.

As the outlook continues to sour, some growth investors are forging a new path. Coatue Management, the fund run by Coleman's fellow “Tiger cub” Philippe Laffont, is raising $2bn for a structured equity strategy, which lends money to cash-strapped private companies unwilling to raise dilutive equity financing at depressed valuations. 

“I felt that we needed to use the crisis to think of a new way of doing things,” Laffont told the FT. 

Others have been less inclined to accept defeat. On Tuesday, Wood's Ark embarked on its biggest stock-buying spree since February, according to Bloomberg, scooping up 27 stocks across its eight exchange traded funds even as Wall Street suffered its worst sell-off since June of 2020.

“Buy the dip” has been a rallying cry of growth investors for years. That theory is being put to the test.

Call of Duty: antitrust ops

Microsoft's huge bet on gaming is attracting the attention of regulators on a global scale.

The tech giant's $75bn acquisition of video game maker Activision Blizzard is facing extensive antitrust investigations in both London and Brussels following concerns by rivals, including Sony, that it will exclude them from accessing blockbuster game Call of Duty.

The companies have been in talks with regulators in Brussels since the deal was announced eight months ago — an indication of how rigorously officials intend to investigate the deal.

Meanwhile in the UK, the Competition and Markets Authority is expected to launch a “phase 2” probe into the transaction this week unless it sees a serious commitment by Microsoft to preserve competition.

Microsoft hopes to close the deal by next June. But that could be wishful thinking.

“It's not going to be a walk in the park for Microsoft,” a person with direct knowledge of the probe in Brussels told DD's Javier Espinoza.

Microsoft has defended its largest-ever deal by arguing that Call of Duty, the blockbuster game that has brought in $30bn in lifetime sales for Activision, will remain available on other companies' game consoles after the transaction rather than being turned into an exclusive title on Microsoft's Xbox.

Regulators seem unwilling to take the US tech company's word for it. EU watchdogs have cleared Big Tech acquisitions of smaller rivals in the past, including Facebook's purchases of WhatsApp and Instagram, but regret not going after so-called killer acquisitions in the past.

Expect a drawn-out fight.

Job moves

  • Bank of America has appointed Baxter International chief executive and chair José Almeida to its board of directors.

  • Citigroup has hired Barry Weir, a JPMorgan Chase veteran known for working on mining deals, as a managing director in London, according to an internal memo seen by DD.

  • Private equity firm Francisco Partners has hired Erin Blake as a managing director of legal M&A in San Francisco and Jason Warner joins as head of data science in New York. They join from Kirkland & Ellis and Blackstone, respectively.

  • Law firm Hogan Lovells has appointed John Livesey as a partner in the firm's global private equity practice, based in London. He joins from Linklaters.

Smart reads

Swing and a miss PGA Tour commissioner Jay Monahan has touted the tour's prudent financial management to incentivise players not to defect to Saudi Arabia-backed LIV Golf. But his high-flying lifestyle clashes with that narrative, the Wall Street Journal reports.

Business and politics Italy's incoming government will be tasked with deciding the futures of local lender Monte dei Paschi di Siena and restructured national airline ITA. The real test is whether they can resist meddling in ailing companies for political gain, the FT's Silvia Sciorilli Borrelli writes.

Fiduciary responsibility An $800mn lawsuit by Georgian billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili against a trust owned by Credit Suisse could prompt international banks, who oversee trust firms catering to ultra-wealthy clients, to re-examine their strategies, Bloomberg reports.
